[![How To Use Reedsy‚Äôs Book Editor To Format Ebooks And Print For Free](https://selfpublishingadvice.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/06/reedsy.png.webp)](https://selfpublishingadvice.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/06/reedsy.png.webp "Enlarge Image")

# How to Use Reedsy‚Äôs Book Editor to Format Ebooks and Print for Free

- August 3, 2017

_**![headshot of Ricardo Fayet](https://selfpublishingadvice.org/wp-content/uploads/formidable/Ricardo-Fayet-226x300.jpg)Ricardo Fayet** of ALLi partner member **Reedsy** explains the ins and outs of their new tool to help indie authors format ebooks¬†and print books for self-publishing ¬†‚Äì a simple and free process. For the sake of objectivity, he also makes clear its limitations, which many users will be happy to accept in return for the bargain price of $0!_

The typesetting (or formatting) stage is one of the most overlooked ones in the publishing process. After all, formatting won't change the essence of your book (like revising or editing can), and it doesn't influence readers' purchases like a good cover will.

![photo of holding a book open](https://selfpublishingadvice.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/How-to-format-a-book-Hiding-Haelo-Open-1024x683.jpg.webp)

And yet, the way a book looks on the inside is usually one of the clearest indicators of the level of professionalism the author has put into producing it.

If you've ever tried turning a Word document into an EPUB or a print-ready PDF file, you'll know that the most popular word processors aren‚Äôt meant for making books. Hence the success of dedicated formatting tools like Vellum, Calibre, or Jutoh.

At Reedsy, we wanted to approach formatting and typesetting from a different, simpler perspective.

## Philosophy of the Reedsy Book Editor

The idea behind the [Reedsy Book Editor](https://reedsy.com/write-a-book) was to democratize high-quality book production. With that in mind, we built a tool that is: a) completely free, b) accessible through every device and browser, and c) involves no learning curve whatsoever.

Now, when it comes to typesetting for print, there are very specific rules which tend to require a certain learning curve. You need to take into account things like margins, spacing, indents, images, widows, orphans‚Ä¶

The Reedsy Book Editor takes care of all these issues automatically. For the author, this means two things:

1. You don't need to know _anything_ about typesetting to get a perfect-looking PDF that will be accepted by all major POD distributors;
2. You won't have to navigate through hundreds of fancy features that could potentially mess up the typesetting.

For example, you don‚Äôt choose your own font, or size, or spacing. All these typesetting decisions are controlled by the software based on the template you select, a feature noted by indie author Tara Holladay when she used the Reedsy Book Editor for her novel _Hiding Haelo._

‚ÄúI love that I didn't have to worry about weird, unexpected formatting quirks. All the paragraphs indented properly without hidden tabs. The alignment was uniform throughout unless I needed specific sections aligned differently, which only took one click: really easy to do.‚Äù

While the limited customization options has been frustrating to some, it's the only way to ensure that the end result will _always_ be perfect.

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt have a huge variety of choice in how things appear at the moment,‚Äù says writer (and soon-to-be ALLi member) Rebecca Milton, ‚Äúbut the service is still in its early days ‚Äî and the options you have are plenty.‚Äù

Authors can currently choose between three templates:

- **Reedsy:** the perfect choice for non-fiction
- **Classic:** for a style similar to Penguin Classics
- **Romance:** which is for‚Ä¶ well, you can probably guess

And over the next few months, we‚Äôll be looking to roll out even more new themes.

## How to format a book for both EPUB and print within the Editor

### Step 1: Importing your book

Okay, this is probably the one frustrating step left in the process. Importing your book to the Editor requires you to copy-and-paste your book a chapter at a time.

![image of import screen](https://selfpublishingadvice.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/Import-into-the-Reedsy-Book-Editor.gif.webp)

We're working on a smarter import feature but for now, you'll need to spend five-to-ten minutes copy-pasting your manuscript into the interface. The software retains most of your formatting (bolding, italics, etc.), but will remove all the unnecessary code that Word or Google Docs always adds to the text‚Ä¶

### Step 2: Applying the finishing touches

Once you have your entire book in there, you can go through it and apply any final touches using the formatting bar ‚Äî which automatically appears when you highlight text.

![image of style choices](https://selfpublishingadvice.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/Reedsy-formatting-bar-1024x504.jpg.webp)

At this stage, you can also drag and drop images, write captions, or add endnotes.

### Step 3: Configure the front and end matter

The sidebar of the Reedsy Book Editor is separated into 3 sections: the front matter, the body, and the back matter. If you're not familiar with the anatomy of a book, you can read more about these sections in [this post](https://blog.reedsy.com/front-matter-back-matter-book/).

![screenshot](https://selfpublishingadvice.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/Images-and-captions-1024x695.jpg.webp)

Note the sidebar (left) with front matter and back matter sections

Parts of your front matter, like your title and copyright pages, will be automatically generated, based on the info you provide in the book's settings.

‚ÄúThe _book settings_ feature keeps all of your info in one place,‚Äù says Tara Holladay. ‚ÄúYou don't have to guess what to put on the copyright page: it's all done for you. Just enter your title, author name, ISBN, publisher information, logo, description, and then all of the front matter and first level metadata is done for you.‚Äù

### 3: Export your book

This is the fun part. Once everything is ready, you can head to the export page and choose between EPUB or PDF export.

Here's where you can customize your book a bit more and choose:

- your template
- whether you want drop caps
- where you want your end notes
- your trim size (for print)

Then, simply hit ‚Äúexport‚Äù and you‚Äôll receive the formatted book within seconds (for ebook) or minutes (for print) in your email inbox.

When it came to self-publishing his debut novel, _The Crossing,_ author Michael Doane decided to try out the Reedsy Book Editor.

‚ÄúIt made formatting, exporting, and publishing a breeze,‚Äù Doane says. ‚ÄúI simply dropped in my text from a word processor, selected a few options, and within minutes had a beautiful, professionally formatted file that I could upload to Amazon, Barnes & Noble, and every other major retailer.‚Äù

To make sure your files will be accepted on the first try, we‚Äôve tested our EPUBs with every major retailer and distributor, and our PDFs with Createspace, IngramSpark, and Blurb. In fact, we‚Äôve recently partnered with Blurb to let you send your Reedsy-formatted PDF to them with a single click.

![copy of Halo book](https://selfpublishingadvice.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/Hiding-Haelo-1024x683.jpg.webp)

T.M Holladay‚Äôs Hiding Haelo, formatted with the Reedsy Book Editor and printed by Createspace

_Note: there is no ‚Äúpreview‚Äù feature within the Reedsy Book Editor. If you make a formatting change and want to see what the end result looks like, you'll need to run another export._

## What are its limitations?

I was asked to write an honest post about the Reedsy Book Editor, so it‚Äôs only fair that I dedicate the last section to the limitations of this free software.

### 1\. It's browser-based

We like to think of this as a positive because you can access it from almost any device and browser through your Reedsy account. But it also means you'll need an active internet connection, as there‚Äôs no app to download.

### 2\. It's not for image or illustration-heavy books

If you want to produce a cookbook or a coffee-table book, we would not recommend the Reedsy Book Editor. You can insert images, but you will have trouble arranging text around them. This higher level of design complexity needs to be handled properly with software like InDesign.

### 3\. Customization is limited

As I mentioned earlier, only a few templates are available for now. That and you won't be able to use fancy fonts for drop caps or chapter titles.

But on the other hand, our existing templates (including their fonts) have been designed by professional typesetters based on widely-used industry standards.

### 4\. There's no .mobi export

The reason for this is simple: if your EPUB is formatted correctly, you can upload that file to KDP, and they'll do the conversion. We've run repeated tests to ensure that Amazon converts our EPUBs seamlessly (which it does). But if you want to export or customize your .mobi directly, you'll need to use another tool.

![reedsy](https://selfpublishingadvice.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/06/reedsy-300x80.png.webp)And that's it! I hope I‚Äôve shed some light onto what you can (and cannot) do with the Reedsy Book Editor. Even though it's a free product, we do spend a considerable amount of time and resources refining it: if you've used the tool and have any feedback, we'd love to hear it!

**OVER TO YOU** Have you used Reedsy's Book Editor yet? Feel free to share your case studies via the comments box!

[#Authors - have you heard about @ReedsyHQ's new free book formatting tool?     Until they can fix that very basic issue, it‚Äôs unusable to me.

    1. ![](https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/4373a73baf1d6c1db13ef588c82dc517ace99e74d0b1cd51483f387ac2da4b36?s=50&d=blank&r=r)**[Ricardo Fayet](https://reedsy.com/write-a-book)** says:

08. ![](https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/624021886cfeffe48863a0bab0bb1efea19e8b58198ba600f789349e26c4f753?s=50&d=blank&r=r)**[L. Silvestri](http://none/)** says:



    [April 24, 2019 at 9:22 AM](https://selfpublishingadvice.org/how-to-use-reedsys-book-editor-to-format-ebooks-and-print/#comment-874612)





    When creating a manuscript of short stories in Libreoffice Writer, for self-publishing, what I do for first page of every story is


    Manually space down 6 spaces from top of page for title of each story. Type in title of story. Then center title. Then, 2 spaces down for text of story.


    Is that the way it‚Äôs done? Or, can this be set up automatically for each story?



    Thanks.





    [Reply](https://selfpublishingadvice.org/how-to-use-reedsys-book-editor-to-format-ebooks-and-print/#comment-874612)

09. ![](https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/2c4bd17247a98737e67ff38cd2ce947e899c5cb29fd0fea5598e15068c59b0e0?s=50&d=blank&r=r)**[Cameron Powell](http://www.ordinarymagicbook.com/)** says:



    [August 10, 2017 at 6:45 PM](https://selfpublishingadvice.org/how-to-use-reedsys-book-editor-to-format-ebooks-and-print/#comment-746537)





    Fro me, the Reedsy editor is not what, in the startup world, we refer to as an MVP ‚Äì a minimum viable product, or the least that you want to go to market with.



    Having to cut and paste, in my case, dozens of chapters, is not only a pain that other free editors have already solved ‚Äì I make my chapter headings H1 and their software takes care of the rest ‚Äì but doesn‚Äôt acknowledge how many writers actually work.



    We work iteratively. Once I get a manuscript into an ebook converter, I send it out for comment. I read it myself in a format that looks very different from Word. Then there are changes to the text. Those changes need to be made in the original Word document. And then the cutting and pasting begins again?



    Reedy‚Äôs editor means everything I‚Äôve done to get the book in the editor is lost, and I need to start over.





    [Reply](https://selfpublishingadvice.org/how-to-use-reedsys-book-editor-to-format-ebooks-and-print/#comment-746537)

    1. ![](https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/4373a73baf1d6c1db13ef588c82dc517ace99e74d0b1cd51483f387ac2da4b36?s=50&d=blank&r=r)**[Ricardo Fayet](https://reedsy.com/)** says:



       [August 16, 2017 at 11:34 AM](https://selfpublishingadvice.org/how-to-use-reedsys-book-editor-to-format-ebooks-and-print/#comment-747356)





       I totally hear you on the copying and pasting. We‚Äôre working on an import function (a bit more sophisticated than what other editing tools do‚Ä¶) right now, which will make the process smoother.



       However, re working iteratively, I think there is a misunderstanding here as to how our Reedsy Book Editor works. It‚Äôs actually more than just an ‚Äúebook converter‚Äù, it‚Äôs a proper writing and formatting tool. After you‚Äôve imported your manuscript (by copying and pasting), you can then make changes directly in there, from any device ‚Äî in a much better interface than Word or other writing tools ‚Äî and then re-export the EPUB or PDF. So you never need to go back to Word, you have your final manuscript file safely backed up on Reedsy.



       In fact, we‚Äôve had many authors write their whole manuscript directly in there already. Justin Jackson did a pretty good video tutorial of it: [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GIG-Q8Hg0oM](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GIG-Q8Hg0oM)





       [Reply](https://selfpublishingadvice.org/how-to-use-reedsys-book-editor-to-format-ebooks-and-print/#comment-747356)

       1. ![](https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/86588bf497cac5f6c75eaa9fd25a7f1b4b2e830bf9d1b913922519ea660e5dd6?s=50&d=blank&r=r)**Chris Tooker** says:



          [May 24, 2020 at 9:17 PM](https://selfpublishingadvice.org/how-to-use-reedsys-book-editor-to-format-ebooks-and-print/#comment-1438276)





          Have you resolved the importing issue so you no longer have to cut and paste each chapter





          [Reply](https://selfpublishingadvice.org/how-to-use-reedsys-book-editor-to-format-ebooks-and-print/#comment-1438276)

          1. ![](https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/4373a73baf1d6c1db13ef588c82dc517ace99e74d0b1cd51483f387ac2da4b36?s=50&d=blank&r=r)**[Ricardo Fayet](https://reedsy.com/write-a-book)** says:



             [November 12, 2020 at 8:36 AM](https://selfpublishingadvice.org/how-to-use-reedsys-book-editor-to-format-ebooks-and-print/#comment-1636051)





             Yes, the Reedsy Book Editor has had a Word import feature for a couple of years now, which works seamlessly and keeps your formatting and chapters ‚Äî if they‚Äôre correctly styled using ‚Äúheading‚Äù styles.





             [Reply](https://selfpublishingadvice.org/how-to-use-reedsys-book-editor-to-format-ebooks-and-print/#comment-1636051)
    2. ![](https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/4373a73baf1d6c1db13ef588c82dc517ace99e74d0b1cd51483f387ac2da4b36?s=50&d=blank&r=r)**[Ricardo Fayet](https://reedsy.com/write-a-book)** says:



       [November 12, 2020 at 8:39 AM](https://selfpublishingadvice.org/how-to-use-reedsys-book-editor-to-format-ebooks-and-print/#comment-1636054)





       First, sorry for the delay in getting back to you ‚Äî I don‚Äôt receive notifications for comments on here.


       I think there is some confusion as to what the Reedsy Book Editor is: it‚Äôs not just a ‚Äúconverter‚Äù, it‚Äôs a writing AND formatting tool. Meaning that once you have the content in there, you can change the content directly in there ‚Äî you don‚Äôt need to go back to Word ever again. Heck, many people are actually writing their books directly in the Editor now.


       As for importing, we now have an import function that will keep the formatting and automatically recognise chapters if the Word document is formatted correctlly.





       [Reply](https://selfpublishingadvice.org/how-to-use-reedsys-book-editor-to-format-ebooks-and-print/#comment-1636054)
10. ![](https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/2e338371486a80419c47c36edcc0b4a5ac2b6d13707a3697d32fb1bdca87cf85?s=50&d=blank&r=r)**Mark Williams Int.** says:



    [August 6, 2017 at 9:54 AM](https://selfpublishingadvice.org/how-to-use-reedsys-book-editor-to-format-ebooks-and-print/#comment-745744)





    Ricardo, it would be really helpful if, when we clicked on the link to the book editor, we actually got taken to the book editor.



    Instead we have to login and immediately find ourselves on the market-place page, and there is no link anywhere to the book editor.



    In fact the book editor is hidden away in My Books ‚Äì not the place a first-time user is going to look because by definition they have no books at that point.





    [Reply](https://selfpublishingadvice.org/how-to-use-reedsys-book-editor-to-format-ebooks-and-print/#comment-745744)

    1. ![](https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/4373a73baf1d6c1db13ef588c82dc517ace99e74d0b1cd51483f387ac2da4b36?s=50&d=blank&r=r)**[Ricardo Fayet](https://reedsy.com/)** says:



       [August 16, 2017 at 11:36 AM](https://selfpublishingadvice.org/how-to-use-reedsys-book-editor-to-format-ebooks-and-print/#comment-747357)





       Thanks for your comment, Mark. You‚Äôre absolutely right, and we‚Äôll be making the Reedsy Book Editor more prominent and easier to access as we keep building and improving it.



       The plan is to integrate it with the marketplace as it becomes collaborative (with track changes, commenting, etc.). Right now, our main product is the marketplace and we still want to make sure that authors see it when they log in to Reedsy.



       Again, thanks for your feedback!





       [Reply](https://selfpublishingadvice.org/how-to-use-reedsys-book-editor-to-format-ebooks-and-print/#comment-747357)
11. ![](https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/78f6432531dad293f0e06d1ba6e1e0ce5539b3e9c72e99e4cb279ffffdf4c592?s=50&d=blank&r=r)**[Rebecca Milton](http://www.rebecca-milton.com/)** says:



    [August 3, 2017 at 3:55 PM](https://selfpublishingadvice.org/how-to-use-reedsys-book-editor-to-format-ebooks-and-print/#comment-745388)





    Thanks for the quote, Ricardo ‚Äì though I have to mention that my surname is Milton, not Hamilton! (Much as I might wish to be linked to the musical).



    I really rate this tool and it‚Äôs great to see an article explaining its pros and cons so clearly.





    [Reply](https://selfpublishingadvice.org/how-to-use-reedsys-book-editor-to-format-ebooks-and-print/#comment-745388)

    1. ![](https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/4373a73baf1d6c1db13ef588c82dc517ace99e74d0b1cd51483f387ac2da4b36?s=50&d=blank&r=r)**[Ricardo Fayet](https://reedsy.com/)** says:



       [August 16, 2017 at 11:37 AM](https://selfpublishingadvice.org/how-to-use-reedsys-book-editor-to-format-ebooks-and-print/#comment-747358)





       Ooooops! Sorry about that, I‚Äôll make sure we correct that as soon as we can üôÅ


       And thanks for the kind words re the article!





       [Reply](https://selfpublishingadvice.org/how-to-use-reedsys-book-editor-to-format-ebooks-and-print/#comment-747358)

## Latest advice, news, ratings, tools and trends.

[![AI Copyright Warning](https://selfpublishingadvice.org/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/News-February-19-700x350.jpg)](https://selfpublishingadvice.org/ai-copyright-warning/ "News Summary: UK Independent Publishers Issue AI Copyright Warning; TikTok Backs National Year of Reading")

### [News Summary: UK Independent Publishers Issue AI Copyright Warning; TikTok Backs National Year of Reading](https://selfpublishingadvice.org/ai-copyright-warning/)

The first story today brings a real sense of d√©j√† vu. Not just because "another copyright-related legal battle against tech firms" is hardly new. It's hardly d√©j√† vu either: more "here we go again." It's more that the latest action from the Independent Publishers Guild (IPG) is strikingly familiar in form to the action we saw from the Society of Authors some time ago.

[Read more](https://selfpublishingadvice.org/ai-copyright-warning/)

[![Why Recipes For Publishing Success Don't Work](https://selfpublishingadvice.org/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/BANNER_PfP_Joe-622x350.jpg)](https://selfpublishingadvice.org/why-recipes-for-publishing-success-dont-work/ "Why Recipes for Publishing Success Don‚Äôt Work‚Äîand What to Do Instead, with Joe Solari")

### [Why Recipes for Publishing Success Don‚Äôt Work‚Äîand What to Do Instead, with Joe Solari](https://selfpublishingadvice.org/why-recipes-for-publishing-success-dont-work/)

On the Self-Publishing with ALLi podcast, Joe Solari explores why publishing success formulas so often fail. Drawing on a landmark study of cultural markets, he explains how randomness and social feedback loops mean that even books of similar quality can have wildly different outcomes. The good news? The market isn't locked‚Äînew winners emerge constantly. Rather than chasing guaranteed recipes, Solari argues authors should focus on building durable advantages and staying in the game long enough for luck to find them.

[Read more](https://selfpublishingadvice.org/why-recipes-for-publishing-success-dont-work/)

[![Italian Piracy](https://selfpublishingadvice.org/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/News-February-17-700x350.jpg)](https://selfpublishingadvice.org/italian-piracy/ "News Summary: Italian Piracy Report Shows University Students Lead Downloads; AI Content Marketplaces Emerge")

### [News Summary: Italian Piracy Report Shows University Students Lead Downloads; AI Content Marketplaces Emerge](https://selfpublishingadvice.org/italian-piracy/)

While the focus for ALLi's news is the Anglophone marketplace, it is often the case that stories from other territories are of direct interest. And that's the case with this week's first story, looking at a recent report from Italy. Thanks to Publishing Perspectives for highlighting this.

[Read more](https://selfpublishingadvice.org/italian-piracy/)
